title: How to Make Vol‐Au‐Vent

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C) and unroll the puff pastry.
steps.description: Take the thawed puff pastry out of the package and unroll 2 sheets. Lay both sheets flat on your work surface so you can cut the cases out. If you prefer, make your own puff pastry instead of buying it.

steps.headline: Cut at least 6 circles out of each pastry sheet.
steps.description: Since most puff pastry sheets measure around 10 by 13 inches (25 cm × 33 cm), you should be able to cut 6 circles that are 3 ⁄2 inches (8.9 cm) in diameter. You should get 12 circles once you've cut both of the puff pastry sheets. If you'd like to make smaller cases, use a 2 ⁄4 inches (5.7 cm) round cutter.

steps.headline: Use a small round cutter to remove the centers from 6 of the circles.
steps.description: Take a 2 in (5.1 cm) round cutter and cut out the centers from half of the puff pastry rounds. These rings will form the sides of the pastry cases. Keep the small center rounds that you remove. You'll bake these and can use them as lids for the vol-au-vent.

steps.headline: Line a baking sheet with parchment and lay the whole circles on it.
steps.description: Lay a sheet of parchment paper on a baking sheet and use a metal spatula to transfer the 6 whole circles onto the sheet. Leave at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) of space between each circle.

steps.headline: Brush the circles with beaten egg and lay the rings on them.
steps.description: Dip a pastry brush into the beaten egg and brush it over each of the whole circles on the baking sheet. Then place 1 of the puff pastry rings directly onto each circle and brush the rings with the beaten egg. You should also put the small circular pieces you cut out onto the sheet and brush them with egg.Did You Know? Brushing beaten egg over the puff pastry will give it a deep golden color as it bakes. The beaten egg will help the circle and ring stick together.

steps.headline: Make shallow cuts along the center and ring of each case.
steps.description: Use the dull side of a small knife to make shallow cuts along the outside of the puff pastry rings. This will force the pastry to puff up as it bakes. Then make a few shallow cuts in the center of the pastry case near the bottom. Making the cuts on the bottom center of the pastry case will prevent it from puffing up too much so it's easier to fill later.

steps.headline: Chill the puff pastry cases for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Put the sheet of cut and shaped puff pastry cases in the refrigerator to rest for 20 minutes. Chilling the pastry will help it hold its shape when it bakes.

steps.headline: Bake the cases for 10 to 12 minutes.
steps.description: Remove the baking sheet from the refrigerator and put the puff pastry cases into the preheated oven. Let them bake for 10 to 12 minutes without opening the oven door to check on them. They should turn rich golden brown and puff up dramatically. Let the puff pastry cases cool while you prepare a filling of your choice. You can bake the puff pastry cases and store them in an airtight container for up to 2 days before filling them, but the texture will be the best on the day they're baked.

methods.name: Smoked Salmon and Cream Cheese Filling

steps.headline: Blend the cream cheese and dill for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Put 4 ounces (112 g) of room temperature cream cheese into a food processor. Add 1/2 of a finely chopped shallot and blend the mixture until it's smooth and the shallot is completely combined.

steps.headline: Mix in sriracha, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Blend in ⁄8 teaspoon (0.62 ml) of sriracha sauce and then taste the cream cheese mixture. Blend in salt and pepper according to your taste.

steps.headline: Fold in the chives, dill, and lemon zest.
steps.description: Finely slice enough chives to measure 1 tablespoon (3.5 g) of chives and finely chop enough fresh dill to measure 1 tablespoon (0.2 g). Add these to the cream cheese mixture along with the zest of 1/2 of a lemon. Use a large metal spoon to fold the herbs and zest into the cream cheese.Did You Know? Folding the seasonings in gently instead of stirring vigorously will keep the cream cheese mixture light and fluffy. This will make it easy to pipe.

steps.headline: Pipe the cream cheese mixture into the baked pastry cases.
steps.description: Once the puff pastry vol-au-vent cases are baked and cooled, fill a piping bag with the cream cheese mixture. Then pipe the mixture into each case until they're full.

steps.headline: Garnish the vol-au-vent with smoked salmon and dill.
steps.description: Slice 1 ounce (28 g) of smoked salmon into 9 small strips or squares. The size you cut them will depend on the size salmon you have. Place a piece of the smoked salmon on top of each vol-au-vent and place a few baby dill leaves on them before serving. Avoid storing leftover vol-au-vent since the pastry will become soggy as the cream cheese mixture sits in it.

steps.headline: Mince the wild mushrooms and smash the garlic clove.
steps.description: Get out 1 cup (75 g) of wild mixed mushrooms and finely chop them so they're uniform in size. Peel 1 garlic clove and push down on it until it's smashed. You can use the flat blade of a chef's knife or the bottom of a glass to smash the garlic clove.

steps.headline: Sauté the mushrooms, garlic, and time for 4 minutes.
steps.description: Melt 1 1/2 tablespoons (21 g) of butter in a skillet over medium heat. Stir in the finely chopped mushrooms, garlic clove, and 2 stems of fresh thyme. Cook the mushroom mixture until the mushrooms release their liquid and shrink.Did You Know? It's important to cook off the mushroom liquid so the filling doesn't have too much moisture which would make the vol-au-vent soggy.

steps.headline: Add the white wine and cook the mixture for 1 to 2 minutes.
steps.description: Pour in 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of dry white wine and continue to cook the mushrooms over medium. Stir and cook the filling until the wine is almost evaporated. For dry white wine, use chardonnay, Pinot Grigio, or Sauvignon Blanc.

steps.headline: Remove the garlic and thyme before stirring in the crème fraîche.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and scoop out the smashed garlic clove. Discard the garlic and the thyme sprigs. Then stir in 2 tablespoons (29 g) of crème fraîche.

steps.headline: Spoon the mushroom filling into the vol-au-vent cases.
steps.description: Taste the filling and add salt and pepper according to your taste. Then divide the filling among 9 baked and cooled puff pastry cases. Serve the vol-au-vent immediately. Since the puff pastry will become soggy as it sits, don't store leftover vol-au-vent.

steps.headline: Chop the bacon and heat a skillet over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Cut 6 slices of bacon into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces and set a skillet on the stove. Turn the burner to medium-high and let the skillet heat for a few minutes.

steps.headline: Fry the bacon for 7 to 10 minutes and drain it.
steps.description: Add the bacon to the skillet and cook it until the bacon becomes crispy and fully cooked. Stir frequently to prevent the bacon from sticking. Then transfer the bacon bits to a paper towel-lined plate. The amount of time it takes to fry the bacon will vary depending on what type of bacon you're using, how fatty it is, how thick it is, and the type of skillet you're using.

steps.headline: Sauté the leeks and pepper for 5 to 7 minutes.
steps.description: Drain off all but 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of the bacon grease in the skillet and keep the burner turned to medium-high. Add 2 sliced leeks and 1 diced yellow bell pepper. Stir and cook the vegetables until they soften.Did You Know? Although you can use orange or red bell peppers, the yellow bell peppers will have the mildest flavor. For a sweeter flavor, use red bell peppers.

steps.headline: Add the bacon, chicken, cheese, and seasonings to the skillet.
steps.description: Put the crispy bacon bits in the skillet with the vegetables and add 1 cup (125 g) of shredded rotisserie chicken along with 8 ounces (225 g) of softened cream cheese, 1/4 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt, and 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of ground pepper. It's important to use softened cream cheese since cold cream cheese will become lumpy.

steps.headline: Cook the filling over low heat for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the burner down to low and stir the mixture well. Continue to stir and cook until the cream cheese mixes with the vegetables, chicken, and bacon. Then turn off the burner.

steps.headline: Fill the cooled puff pastry cases.
steps.description: Get out 6 baked and cooled vol-au-vent cases and use a spoon to divide the creamy chicken filling between them. Since the filling should be hot it's important to serve the vol-au-vent right after you assemble them. Avoid storing leftover vol-au-vent because the puff pastry will become soggy.

text: Puff Pastry Cases Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C) and unroll the puff pastry. Take the thawed puff pastry out of the package and unroll 2 sheets. Lay both sheets flat on your work surface so you can cut the cases out. If you prefer, make your own puff pastry instead of buying it. Cut at least 6 circles out of each pastry sheet. Since most puff pastry sheets measure around 10 by 13 inches (25 cm × 33 cm), you should be able to cut 6 circles that are 3 ⁄2 inches (8.9 cm) in diameter. You should get 12 circles once you've cut both of the puff pastry sheets. If you'd like to make smaller cases, use a 2 ⁄4 inches (5.7 cm) round cutter. Use a small round cutter to remove the centers from 6 of the circles. Take a 2 in (5.1 cm) round cutter and cut out the centers from half of the puff pastry rounds. These rings will form the sides of the pastry cases. Keep the small center rounds that you remove. You'll bake these and can use them as lids for the vol-au-vent. Line a baking sheet with parchment and lay the whole circles on it. Lay a sheet of parchment paper on a baking sheet and use a metal spatula to transfer the 6 whole circles onto the sheet. Leave at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) of space between each circle. Brush the circles with beaten egg and lay the rings on them. Dip a pastry brush into the beaten egg and brush it over each of the whole circles on the baking sheet. Then place 1 of the puff pastry rings directly onto each circle and brush the rings with the beaten egg. You should also put the small circular pieces you cut out onto the sheet and brush them with egg.Did You Know? Brushing beaten egg over the puff pastry will give it a deep golden color as it bakes. The beaten egg will help the circle and ring stick together. Make shallow cuts along the center and ring of each case. Use the dull side of a small knife to make shallow cuts along the outside of the puff pastry rings. This will force the pastry to puff up as it bakes. Then make a few shallow cuts in the center of the pastry case near the bottom. Making the cuts on the bottom center of the pastry case will prevent it from puffing up too much so it's easier to fill later. Chill the puff pastry cases for 20 minutes. Put the sheet of cut and shaped puff pastry cases in the refrigerator to rest for 20 minutes. Chilling the pastry will help it hold its shape when it bakes. Bake the cases for 10 to 12 minutes. Remove the baking sheet from the refrigerator and put the puff pastry cases into the preheated oven. Let them bake for 10 to 12 minutes without opening the oven door to check on them. They should turn rich golden brown and puff up dramatically. Let the puff pastry cases cool while you prepare a filling of your choice. You can bake the puff pastry cases and store them in an airtight container for up to 2 days before filling them, but the texture will be the best on the day they're baked. Smoked Salmon and Cream Cheese Filling Blend the cream cheese and dill for 2 minutes. Put 4 ounces (112 g) of room temperature cream cheese into a food processor. Add 1/2 of a finely chopped shallot and blend the mixture until it's smooth and the shallot is completely combined. Mix in sriracha, salt, and pepper. Blend in ⁄8 teaspoon (0.62 ml) of sriracha sauce and then taste the cream cheese mixture. Blend in salt and pepper according to your taste. Fold in the chives, dill, and lemon zest. Finely slice enough chives to measure 1 tablespoon (3.5 g) of chives and finely chop enough fresh dill to measure 1 tablespoon (0.2 g). Add these to the cream cheese mixture along with the zest of 1/2 of a lemon. Use a large metal spoon to fold the herbs and zest into the cream cheese.Did You Know? Folding the seasonings in gently instead of stirring vigorously will keep the cream cheese mixture light and fluffy. This will make it easy to pipe. Pipe the cream cheese mixture into the baked pastry cases. Once the puff pastry vol-au-vent cases are baked and cooled, fill a piping bag with the cream cheese mixture. Then pipe the mixture into each case until they're full. Garnish the vol-au-vent with smoked salmon and dill. Slice 1 ounce (28 g) of smoked salmon into 9 small strips or squares. The size you cut them will depend on the size salmon you have. Place a piece of the smoked salmon on top of each vol-au-vent and place a few baby dill leaves on them before serving. Avoid storing leftover vol-au-vent since the pastry will become soggy as the cream cheese mixture sits in it. Mushroom and Thyme Filling Mince the wild mushrooms and smash the garlic clove. Get out 1 cup (75 g) of wild mixed mushrooms and finely chop them so they're uniform in size. Peel 1 garlic clove and push down on it until it's smashed. You can use the flat blade of a chef's knife or the bottom of a glass to smash the garlic clove. Sauté the mushrooms, garlic, and time for 4 minutes. Melt 1 1/2 tablespoons (21 g) of butter in a skillet over medium heat. Stir in the finely chopped mushrooms, garlic clove, and 2 stems of fresh thyme. Cook the mushroom mixture until the mushrooms release their liquid and shrink.Did You Know? It's important to cook off the mushroom liquid so the filling doesn't have too much moisture which would make the vol-au-vent soggy. Add the white wine and cook the mixture for 1 to 2 minutes. Pour in 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of dry white wine and continue to cook the mushrooms over medium. Stir and cook the filling until the wine is almost evaporated. For dry white wine, use chardonnay, Pinot Grigio, or Sauvignon Blanc. Remove the garlic and thyme before stirring in the crème fraîche. Turn off the burner and scoop out the smashed garlic clove. Discard the garlic and the thyme sprigs. Then stir in 2 tablespoons (29 g) of crème fraîche. Spoon the mushroom filling into the vol-au-vent cases. Taste the filling and add salt and pepper according to your taste. Then divide the filling among 9 baked and cooled puff pastry cases. Serve the vol-au-vent immediately. Since the puff pastry will become soggy as it sits, don't store leftover vol-au-vent. Creamy Chicken and Leek Filling Chop the bacon and heat a skillet over medium-high heat. Cut 6 slices of bacon into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces and set a skillet on the stove. Turn the burner to medium-high and let the skillet heat for a few minutes. Fry the bacon for 7 to 10 minutes and drain it. Add the bacon to the skillet and cook it until the bacon becomes crispy and fully cooked. Stir frequently to prevent the bacon from sticking. Then transfer the bacon bits to a paper towel-lined plate. The amount of time it takes to fry the bacon will vary depending on what type of bacon you're using, how fatty it is, how thick it is, and the type of skillet you're using. Sauté the leeks and pepper for 5 to 7 minutes. Drain off all but 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of the bacon grease in the skillet and keep the burner turned to medium-high. Add 2 sliced leeks and 1 diced yellow bell pepper. Stir and cook the vegetables until they soften.Did You Know? Although you can use orange or red bell peppers, the yellow bell peppers will have the mildest flavor. For a sweeter flavor, use red bell peppers. Add the bacon, chicken, cheese, and seasonings to the skillet. Put the crispy bacon bits in the skillet with the vegetables and add 1 cup (125 g) of shredded rotisserie chicken along with 8 ounces (225 g) of softened cream cheese, 1/4 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt, and 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of ground pepper. It's important to use softened cream cheese since cold cream cheese will become lumpy. Cook the filling over low heat for 2 to 3 minutes. Turn the burner down to low and stir the mixture well. Continue to stir and cook until the cream cheese mixes with the vegetables, chicken, and bacon. Then turn off the burner. Fill the cooled puff pastry cases. Get out 6 baked and cooled vol-au-vent cases and use a spoon to divide the creamy chicken filling between them. Since the filling should be hot it's important to serve the vol-au-vent right after you assemble them. Avoid storing leftover vol-au-vent because the puff pastry will become soggy.
